derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from in- 'not' + disposed, or past participle of indispose 'make unwell or unwilling'

entry.def: If you say that someone is indisposed, you mean that they are not available because they are ill, or for a reason that you do not want to reveal.

example.tran: 很遗憾,演讲人身体不适。

means.word_mean: 1. somewhat ill or prone to illness;

sentences.sentence: "is unwell and can't come to work"
"loath to go on such short notice"

auth_sentence.content: Mr. Allworthy had been for some days indisposed with a cold.
auth_sentence.res_content: Mr. Allworthy had been for some days indisposed with a cold.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Mr. Allworthy had been for some days indisposed with a cold.

auth_sentence.content: We couldn't share it because we were sort of indisposed.
auth_sentence.res_content: We couldn't share it because we were sort of indisposed.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: We couldn't share it because we were sort of indisposed.

auth_sentence.content: He was a little indisposed by a Fall that he had received.
auth_sentence.res_content: He was a little indisposed by a Fall that he had received.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: He was a little indisposed by a Fall that he had received.

stems_affixes.word_buile: dispose安排+ed……的→任安排的→心甘情愿的
